CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: A highly effective photovoltaic polymer with near - infrared response , poly{N- [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione-5 0 ,5 00 -diyl } {PDTP-DTDPP(Bu)} , was synthesized. The polymer has high molecular weight , good solubility , and a broad absorption spectrum in the range of 500-1100 nm. Field effect transistor charge mobility of PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) arrived 0.05 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . Bulk heterojunction type polymer solar cells based on PDTP - DTDPP(Bu) and PC 70 BM have broad photocurrent response wavelength range from 300 nm to 1.1 μm. High short - circuit current ( 14.87 mA / cm^2 ) and power conversion efficiency ( 2.71% ) were achieved , which is a significant advance for efficient photovoltaic polymers that respond to the whole range of the solar spectrum . In the past decade , polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have received a great deal of attention as a potential renewable energy source due to their potential advantages such as low fabrication cost , light weight , and fast production of large area devices by roll - to - roll solution processes. 1 Among photovoltaic polymers , regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) ( P3HT ) has been extensively studied. Bulk heterojunction ( BHJ ) photovoltaic device combining P3HT as the electron donor with [6,6]-phenyl C 61 butyric acid methyl ester ( PCBM ) as the electron acceptor have achieved power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 4-5 % . 2 However , the upper limit seems to have been reached for this material combination , as P3HT utilizes only photons located in the highenergy fraction of the solar spectrum with wavelengths below 650 nm. In fact , ∼ 40% of the total solar energy lies in the range of 650-1100 nm , which is a strong driving force for developing lowbandgap polymers to utilize the solar energy in the near - infrared ( NIR ) range. 3 Recently , significant progress has been made in the photovoltaic application of novel low - bandgap polymers with optical absorption wavelengths in the range of 700-900 nm. 4 Nevertheless , design of efficient photovoltaic polymers with optical absorption and photocurrent response extending to wavelengths of micrometers remains challenging. The first example of this kind of micrometer - response polymer ( μmR - polymer ) was APFO - Green1 , reported by Ingan € as et al. in 2004.^5 Subsequently , considerable effort has been devoted to the design and synthesize of μmR - polymers via a synthetic strategy of combining electronrich units ( donors ) and electron - deficient units ( acceptors ) in a copolymer main chain. To date , no more than 10 μmR - polymers have been synthesized , which are primarily based on a very strong electron - deficient unit such as [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline , 6 thienopyrazine , 7 or thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole.

Let's think step by step.

1. Poly{N- [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione-5 0 ,5 00 -diyl } {PDTP-DTDPP(Bu)}: This is the name of the synthesized photovoltaic polymer.
2. Poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT): This is the name of another photovoltaic polymer that has been extensively studied.
3. [6,6]-phenyl C 61 butyric acid methyl ester (PCBM): This is the name of the electron acceptor used in the photovoltaic device with P3HT.
4. APFO - Green1: This is the name of the first example of a micrometer-response polymer (μmR-polymer).
5. [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline, thienopyrazine, thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole: These are the names of strong electron-deficient units used in the synthesis of μmR-polymers.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. PDTP-DTDPP(Bu)
2. P3HT
3. PCBM
4. APFO - Green1
5. [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline
6. thienopyrazine
7. thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) |
| P3HT |
| PCBM |
| APFO - Green1 |
| [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline |
| thienopyrazine |
| thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole |

Paragraph: A highly effective photovoltaic polymer with near - infrared response , poly{N- [3,4-c]pyrrole-1,4-dione-5 0 ,5 00 -diyl } {PDTP-DTDPP(Bu)} , was synthesized. In fact , ∼ 40% of the total solar energy lies in the range of 650-1100 nm , which is a strong driving force for developing lowbandgap polymers to utilize the solar energy in the near - infrared ( NIR ) range. 3 Recently , significant progress has been made in the photovoltaic application of novel low - bandgap polymers with optical absorption wavelengths in the range of 700-900 nm. 4 Nevertheless , design of efficient photovoltaic polymers with optical absorption and photocurrent response extending to wavelengths of micrometers remains challenging. The first example of this kind of micrometer - response polymer ( μmR - polymer ) was APFO - Green1 , reported by Ingan € as et al. in 2004.^5 Subsequently , considerable effort has been devoted to the design and synthesize of μmR - polymers via a synthetic strategy of combining electronrich units ( donors ) and electron - deficient units ( acceptors ) in a copolymer main chain. To date , no more than 10 μmR - polymers have been synthesized , which are primarily based on a very strong electron - deficient unit such as [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline , 6 thienopyrazine , 7 or thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole.

Let's think step by step.

1. PDTP-DTDPP(Bu): This is the name of the synthesized photovoltaic polymer.
2. molecular weight: This is a property of the PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) polymer.
3. good solubility: This is a property of the PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) polymer.
4. absorption spectrum: This is a property of the PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) polymer.
5. 500-1100 nm: This is a range of wavelengths within the absorption spectrum of the PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) polymer.
6. 0.05 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1: This is the field effect transistor charge mobility of the PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) polymer.
7. PC 70 BM: This is a material used in the bulk heterojunction type polymer solar cells.
8. 300 nm to 1.1 μm: This is the broad photocurrent response wavelength range of the bulk heterojunction type polymer solar cells.
9. 14.87 mA / cm^2: This is the high short-circuit current achieved in the bulk heterojunction type polymer solar cells.
10. 2.71%: This is the power conversion efficiency achieved in the bulk heterojunction type polymer solar cells.
11. PSCs: This stands for polymer solar cells, which is a potential renewable energy source.
12. P3HT: This is a photovoltaic polymer that has been extensively studied.
13. PCBM: This is an electron acceptor material used in bulk heterojunction photovoltaic devices with P3HT.
14. 4-5 %: This is the power conversion efficiency achieved in bulk heterojunction photovoltaic devices combining P3HT and PCBM.
15. ∼ 40%: This is the percentage of total solar energy that lies in the range of 650-1100 nm.
16. NIR: This stands for near-infrared.
17. 700-900 nm: This is a range of wavelengths within the optical absorption of novel low-bandgap polymers.
18. μmR-polymer: This is a type of micrometer-response polymer.
19. APFO-Green1: This is the first example of a micrometer-response polymer reported in 2004.
20. [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline, thienopyrazine, thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole: These are strong electron-deficient units used in the synthesis of micrometer-response polymers.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. PDTP-DTDPP(Bu): molecular weight, good solubility, absorption spectrum (500-1100 nm)
2. PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) in bulk heterojunction type polymer solar cells: short-circuit current (14.87 mA / cm^2), power conversion efficiency (2.71%)
3. P3HT: power conversion efficiencies (4-5 %)
4. Low-bandgap polymers: optical absorption wavelengths (700-900 nm)
5. Micrometer-response polymers: -
6. APFO-Green1: -
7. [1,2,5]thiadiazolo [3,4-g]quinoxaline, thienopyrazine, thieno [3,4-c][1,2,5]thiadiazole: -

These are the entities that clearly refer to the property names of materials in the paragraph.

| power conversion efficiency of PDTP-DTDPP(Bu) in bulk heterojunction type polymer solar cells (2.71%) |

| optical absorption wavelengths of low-bandgap polymers (700-900 nm) |
